instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S0 State No boot
threads.message:
Came in with a short on SMC from fake charger, replaced it and now got green/orange light on original 87w charger

<SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> rail present but no boot and no fan spin and of course no VCORE either.

Any pointers will be greatly appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S0 State No boot
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>?
All the other voltages from power on sequence present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S0 State No boot
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 0.021v diode is 0.457 so not shorted
All resistors for <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> are fine
One thing I notice is that on <CHIP>U7710</CHIP> pin 2 PP1V5S0 is 3.3v and pin 6 is 0.8v
All resistors for <CHIP>U7710</CHIP> are fine
L7770 gets 1.5v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S0 State No boot
threads.message: I will check all other voltages, but for now  <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> needs to be solved I think

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S0 State No boot
threads.message:
Start removing <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR>.
If <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is still low, remove power good resistors one by one, until goes high.
Keep in place <RESISTOR>R7967</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S0 State No boot
threads.message: Removed one by one  and tested each time leaving only <RESISTOR>R7967</RESISTOR> and no luck

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S0 State No boot
threads.message:
I just saw on this board <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is pulled up to <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, not to <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>, like in other models.
So, are you missing <SIGNAL>3V3_S0_FET</SIGNAL>?
Post <TRANSISTOR>Q7812</TRANSISTOR>/30 voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S0 State No boot
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S0_FET</SIGNAL> no present on schematics

<TRANSISTOR>Q7812</TRANSISTOR> 
1 Gnd
2 3.3v
3 0v
4 Gnd
5 3.3v
6 0v

<TRANSISTOR>Q7830</TRANSISTOR>
1-2-3 3.3v
4 0v
5 3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S0 State No boot
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>3V3_S0_FET</SIGNAL> no present on schematics"
And what is the output of <TRANSISTOR>Q7830</TRANSISTOR>???
Do we really need to full write the freaky signal names from Apple always?

Do you have 3V at pin1 of <RESISTOR>R7967</RESISTOR>??
If yes, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> must be high, if you removed ALL the other components from pin 2 (apart of <RESISTOR>R7967</RESISTOR>); check if resistor is good.
<CHIP>U7950</CHIP> can also pull it down; check there for corrosion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S0 State No boot
threads.message:
I searched for it on schematics, it shows up when I search for <SIGNAL>3V3_S0_FET</SIGNAL> but on boardview is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>  3.3v
<RESISTOR>R7967</RESISTOR> pin 1 is 3.3v  and 10k pin 2 is 0.021v
<CHIP>U7950</CHIP> was clean under it but replaced it anyways
Removing  <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> resistors one by one and checking each time same result keeping <RESISTOR>R7967</RESISTOR> at all times, even with all but <RESISTOR>R7967</RESISTOR> removed same thing.

I also replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> and checked <RESISTOR>R2584</RESISTOR> but all are OK

I reballed SMC again and same thing, could this be a bad SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S0 State No boot
threads.message:
Did you check it removing <CHIP>U7950</CHIP>?
Any liquid sign at J2550?
Also try removing <RESISTOR>R7974</RESISTOR>.
Keep <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> out of board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S0 State No boot
threads.message:
Just now tested removing <CHIP>U7950</CHIP> same thing
J2550 is clean all around
<TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> now removed for testing again if removing the resistors bring back <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> but no luck
Removing <CHIP>U7950</CHIP> same thing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S0 State No boot
threads.message: Do you still have 3V at pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7967</RESISTOR>?
